title: How to Decorate a Pumpkin Pie

methods.name: Creating Pie Crust Cutouts of Fall Leaves

steps.headline: Use extra pie crust dough to decorate the top of your pumpkin pie.
steps.description: Roll out extra dough on a lightly floured surface until it's about ⁄8 inch (0.32 cm) thick. Make sure your surface is one that can withstand a blade, like a wood or stone cutting board. If you are decorating a purchased pie, purchase a pre-made raw pie crust to use for your cutouts.

steps.headline: Create your cutouts with various leaf-shaped cookie cutters.
steps.description: Press cookie cutters gently into the rolled-out dough, doing your best to utilize it all by keeping your leaves close together. Remove extra dough and, if it's enough, roll it out again to make more leaves. You can also freehand leaves with a knife or pastry wheel if you don't want to purchase cookie cutters. If you don't feel like you're up to the artistic challenge, print out leaf stencils from the internet and use them to trace your shapes. For an extra creative look, mix up the shapes and sizes of your leaves and add veins with a paring knife.

steps.headline: Brush your finished leaves with an egg wash for a shiny look.
steps.description: Create an egg wash by beating 1 egg in a bowl and adding a splash of water or milk. Brush a light layer on top of each leaf using a pastry brush. If you want a sparkle to go with your shine, sprinkle a little white granulated sugar on top of your egg washed leaves.

steps.headline: Arrange your cutouts on your pie before putting it in the oven.
steps.description: This is the fun part! Place leaves around the edge of your pie for a wreath look. Arrange them in the center of the pie in a symmetrical pattern or mimic leaves falling and place them randomly. If you are opting for the wreath look, use some of your egg wash on the back of the leaves to glue them to the crust and to each other.

steps.headline: Bake the pie according to your recipe's instructions.
steps.description: The added crust elements should not affect the baking time of your pumpkin pie. Remove from the oven and allow to cool before serving.

steps.headline: Make or purchase canned whipped cream.
steps.description: Whipped cream pairs well with pumpkin pie so why not use it as decoration? You can make your whipped cream or purchase it if you are on the go. If you are purchasing whipped cream, 1 can will work. If you are making your own, use 2 cups (470 ml) whipping cream.

steps.headline: Fold in 1/4 tablespoon of instant vanilla pudding mix per 1 cup (240 ml) of whipping cream.
steps.description: This trick will stabilize your homemade whipped cream and help your decorations hold their shape and travel well.

steps.headline: Chill your whipped cream.
steps.description: Whipped cream will hold its shape better when cold. Put whipped cream into the fridge for at least 30 minutes before decorating. If you are short on time, it can go into the freezer for 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Chill your pumpkin pie.
steps.description: Make sure your pie has cooled at least to room temperature before decorating with whipped cream. For the best results, chill your pie in the refrigerator for 30 minutes to ensure that the whipped cream won't melt when applied.

steps.headline: Fill a pastry bag with the whipped cream.
steps.description: Spoon your chilled whipped cream into the bag and cap it with a large open star patterned tip for best results. You can improvise a pastry bag in a pinch by using a large zip lock bag with one corner clipped to make an opening.

steps.headline: Create your rosettes.
steps.description: Use 1 hand to guide the tip of your pastry bag and the other hand to gather the bag at the back and lightly push the whipped cream forward. Start each rosette at the middle and spiral the whipped cream outward, making at least 2 full rotations from center. Start at the outer edges of the pie and work inward.

steps.headline: Cover all the exposed pumpkin filling with rosettes.
steps.description: Overlap rosettes when necessary. Fill any empty spots with a swoosh of whipped cream, mimicking the circular lines that form the rosettes.

steps.headline: Dust the top of your rosettes with cinnamon, nutmeg, or powdered cocoa.
steps.description: To avoid overdoing it, sprinkle from 1 foot (30 cm) above, letting the spice fall lightly into the creases and folds of your beautiful rosettes.

steps.headline: Put your finished pie in the fridge until you are ready to serve it.
steps.description: Cover with a lid to protect the rosettes from being damaged, especially if you are traveling with the pie. If possible, wait to make your rosettes on the same day the pie will be served.

steps.headline: Create a design with whole or chopped nuts.
steps.description: Arrange the nuts of your choice on top of your pie to create a border, design, or word. For example, you could use whole pecans or almonds to form a star shape or pattern. If you prefer chopped nuts, try sprinkling them around the border or accenting your crust cut-outs with them.

steps.headline: Use whipped cream to create simple accents and designs.
steps.description: Once your pie has completely cooled, pipe whipped cream around the border or create simple shapes like hearts or swirls. Experiment with different piping tips to achieve different looks with the whipped cream. For example, plain round tips make great polka dots, vines, and letters. Closed star tips make great flower and star shapes.

steps.headline: Use pie crust leftovers to create customized design elements.
steps.description: Use fun cookie cutters to create holiday specific designs or freehand your own ideas. Make a jack-o-lantern face for Halloween or a turkey for Thanksgiving. Create beautiful botanical designs with trees, vines, leaves, and flowers. Play around with simple shapes like stars and hearts around a word or name. Add your designs before you bake the pie.

steps.headline: Top your pumpkin pie with a braided or lattice crust.
steps.description: Make additional crust and cut strips long enough to crisscross over the pie. Cut crust into thinner strips and create braids. Make a lattice pattern with your braided crust or circle the braids for a wreath look. Top your wreath with a bow cutout or add some fall leaves on top of a lattice crust.

steps.headline: Add a layer of toasted marshmallow fluff.
steps.description: Make or purchase marshmallow fluff and add it to your pie after it is baked. Use a spatula to create peaks and swirls of fluff. Set the oven to 450 °F (232 °C) and toast for 5 minutes or until the topping turns golden brown.

steps.headline: Create designs with melted chocolate chips.
steps.description: Pull your pie from the oven halfway through the baking time. Create a simple design like a heart or a spiral in the unfinished custard with chocolate chips. Put the pie back in the oven for the rest of the baking time. Keep in mind that the chocolate will melt and the design you choose will spread out so keep it's best to keep it simple.

steps.headline: Finished.
